D is correct
Ref = https://aws.amazon.com/iam/faqs/

FAQ:
Q: How can IAM users request temporary security credentials for their own use?
IAM users can request temporary security credentials for their own use by calling the AWS STS GetSessionToken API. The default expiration for these temporary credentials is 12 hours; the minimum is 15 minutes, and the maximum is 36 hours.
You can also use temporary credentials with Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)-Protected API Access.
D should be correct
D is the answer
Correct Answer: D
Answer is "D"
D. Require users to use temporary credentials from the get-session token command to sign API calls.
Agreed D. Require users to use temporary credentials from the get-session token command to sign API calls.
I'll go with D

D is correc. 
https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/mfa-iam-user-aws-cli/

choices.D: Require users to use temporary credentials from the get-session token command to sign API calls.
choices.B: Ask the IAM users to log into the AWS Management Console with MFA before making API calls using the CLI.
choices.C: Restrict the IAM users to use of the console, as MFA is not supported for CLI use.
choices.A: Enable MFA on IAM roles, and require IAM users to use role credentials to sign API calls.

questions.question_text:
A company has mandated the use of multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all IAM users, and requires users to make all API-calls using the CLI. However, users are not prompted to enter MFA tokens, and are able to run CLI commands without MFA. In an attempt to enforce MFA, the company attached an IAM policy to all users that denies API calls that have not been authenticated with MFA.
What additional step must be taken to ensure that API calls are authenticated using MFA?

An application is being developed that will be served across a fleet of Amazon EC2 instances, which require a consistent view of persistent data. Items stored vary in size from 1KB to 300MB; the items are read frequently, created occasionally, and often require partial changes without conflict. The data store is not expected to grow beyond 2TB, and items will be expired according to age and content type.
Which AWS service solution meets these requirements?

discussion.content:
Agree C is correct.

Look at the requirements:

- Multiple EC2 Instances use >> NFS Share 
- Consistent view of persistent data >> Requires data consistency.
- Read frequently >> High I/O
- Items will be expired according to age and content type >> Lifecycle schedule

Multiple Amazon EC2 instances can access an Amazon EFS file system at the same time, providing a common data source for workloads and applications running on more than one instance or server.

Amazon EFS provides file system access semantics, such as strong data consistency and file locking >> So changes can be done without conflict.

Amazon EFS is designed to provide the throughput, IOPS, and low latency needed for a broad range of workloads.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/efs/latest/ug/whatisefs.html


Amazon EFS lifecycle management automatically manages cost-effective file storage for your file systems. When enabled, lifecycle management migrates files that have not been accessed for a set period of time to the Infrequent Access (IA) storage class.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/efs/latest/ug/lifecycle-management-efs.html

Reviewed the question again, EFS makes more sense
https://dzone.com/articles/confused-by-aws-storage-options-s3-ebs-amp-efs-explained
You can mount EFS onto several EC2 instances at the same time.

Selected Answer: C
Amazon EFS (Elastic File System) provides a scalable and managed file storage service that can be mounted to multiple EC2 instances concurrently. It offers a consistent view of the file system data across instances, making it suitable for applications that require a consistent view of persistent data.
S3 now also support strong consistency. So this question need to be updated by AWS.

Correct Answer: C
often require partial changes without conflict => EFS
C is the answer

Answer is "C"
Fleet of EC2 instances with high I/O means EFS is best choice.
C. Amazon EFS and a scheduled process to delete files based on age and extension.

A. Amazon S3 buckets with lifecycle policies to delete old objects. - WRONG as Conflicting Consistency
 B. Amazon RDS PostgreSQL and a job that deletes rows based on age and file type columns. - WRONG (varying sizes suggest unstructured data) 
 C. Amazon EFS and a scheduled process to delete files based on age and extension. - CORRECT
 D. An EC2 instance store synced on boot from a central Amazon EBS-backed instance. - Not Persistent

Not A - Lifecycle policies just work on age, not on content/age
Not B - The varying sizes suggest this isnt structured data that would fit well in PostgreSQL
Not D - This works well for READ activities, but not Write/Update

Only option is C
I'll go with C
C. Amazon EFS and a scheduled process to delete files based on age and extension.
How about B
C: keywords here multiple instances, persistent storage, read frequently

C is correct

The question says a "fleet" of EC2 instances
it says "...and content type" so C
I think C is correct one
No mention of Linux ec2 instances, my guess is s3.

I will choose A, you can use storage gateway to map S3 bucket and the lifecycle can be easily configured. 
as for EFS, you have to manually configure a process or script to aging the data compare to S3, which just come out of the box.

comments.content:
Eh, EFS does not allow resources to be updated without conflicts too.

S3 update operations are atomic.
Lifecycle management of EFS supports only file sizes starting from 128Kb, anything smaller will continue to stays in Standard storage..

I think the question is Not implementing Life cycle management.

"The items will be expired according to age and content type."
Meaning, It will not be visible or inaccessbile by app it and does not mean to use s3 life cycle policy to move/delete the the objects from standard to ia or glacier.
is it s3 objects providing consistent view while partial updates ???. No.

discussion.content:
Ans is C : EFS can be shared by fleet of EC2 Instance and can provide consistent View for N number of EC2.
I don't know how people selected D ( that too Instance store ).
D is correct

I think answer is D.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ComponentsAMIs.html

"Root device for an instance launched from the AMI is an instance store volume created from a template stored in Amazon S3"
"Instances that use an instance store volume for the root device automatically have instance store available (the root volume contains the root partition and you can store additional data). You can add persistent storage to your instance by attaching one or more Amazon EBS volumes. Any data on an instance store volume is deleted when the instance fails or terminates."
Correct answer is C ?

I had bought prepaway dump. It has the same ans C.
My prepaway dump is expired now and this site is better so I have chosen to prepare with this website.

C is the right option.
Correct answer is C

choices.A: Amazon S3 buckets with lifecycle policies to delete old objects.
choices.B: Amazon RDS PostgreSQL and a job that deletes rows based on age and file type columns.
choices.D: An EC2 instance store synced on boot from a central Amazon EBS-backed instance.
choices.C: Amazon EFS and a scheduled process to delete files based on age and extension.

discussion.content:
correct answer is D
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/get-started-ipv6.html

D.
IPV4 --> NAT
IPV6--> Egress-Only
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/egress-only-internet-gateway.html#egress-only-internet-gateway-working-with

Selected Answer: B
An internet gateway is a horizontally scalable, redundant, and highly available VPC component that allows communication between instances in the VPC and the internet. By adding a route for ::/0 (IPv6 default route) traffic to the internet gateway, the Administrator enables outbound internet access from the VPC.

Egress-only Internet Gateway is similar to a NAT Gateway but for IPv6

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/egress-only-internet-gateway.html

IPV4 = NAT Instance/Gateway | 0.0.0.0
IPV6 = Egress-Only Internet Gateway | ::/0

Selected Answer: B
As Cyril said, it is needed an internet gw.

The answer is B.

1. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_Internet_Gateway.html 
(Internet access for default and nondefault VPCs)

2. Therefore, you can create an IPv6 subnet and attach it to the IGW for internet access.
IPv6 addresses are globally unique therefore they are public by default...that is to say, they are publicly accessible by default. To protect your instances, you then create an egress-only-internet gateway.

But for both ingress and egress traffic...with key being ingress...egress-only gateway is the wrong answer!!!

The correct answer is B.
Lab it up in your AWS console, it'll be fun I promise :-)

Correct Answer: D
IPv6 doesn't need NAT, but requires an egress-only igw.

D is the answer

IPV6 requires an egress-only on the public subnet, routing all IPV6 traffic to IGW and then 0.0.0.0/0
Answer is "D"
D. Route ::/0 traffic to an egress-only internet gateway

questions.question_text:
A SysOps Administrator created an Amazon VPC with an IPv6 CIDR block, which requires access to the internet. However, access from the internet towards the
VPC is prohibited. After adding and configuring the required components to the VPC, the Administrator is unable to connect to any of the domains that reside on the internet.
What additional route destination rule should the Administrator add to the route tables?

choices.C: Modify the RDS instance using the console to include the Multi-AZ option.
choices.D: Use the modify-db-instance command with the - -ha flag.
choices.A: Switch to an active/passive database pair using the create-db-instance-read-replica with the - -availability-zone flag.
choices.B: Specify high availability when creating a new RDS instance, and live-migrate the data.

discussion.content: C is correct

Selected Answer: C
By modifying the existing RDS instance through the console and enabling the Multi-AZ option, the database will be automatically replicated to a standby replica in a different Availability Zone. In the event of a primary instance failure or maintenance activity, Amazon RDS will automatically failover to the standby replica, minimizing downtime and ensuring high availability.
C is the answer
C is correct however in case you wonder why D is no is due to no "--ha" flag. If "--multi-az" was specifed, that would have been valid too

Answer is "C".
High Availability == Multi AZ or Multi Region
C. Modify the RDS instance using the console to include the Multi-AZ option.
I'll go with C

C is Correct

questions.question_text:
A recent organizational audit uncovered an existing Amazon RDS database that is not currently configured for high availability. Given the critical nature of this database, it must be configured for high availability as soon as possible.
How can this requirement be met?

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: C & E

C,E are correct

choices.A: Implement AWS Shield to protect against unencrypted objects stored in S3 buckets.
choices.E: Implement S3 bucket policies to deny unencrypted objects from being uploaded to the buckets.
choices.C: Implement Amazon S3 default encryption to make sure that any object being uploaded is encrypted before it is stored.
choices.D: Implement Amazon Inspector to inspect objects uploaded to the S3 bucket to make sure that they are encrypted.
choices.B: Implement Object access control list (ACL) to deny unencrypted objects from being uploaded to the S3 bucket.

questions.question_text:
A company must ensure that any objects uploaded to an S3 bucket are encrypted.
Which of the following actions will meet this requirement? (Choose two.)
